sub_topic: Finding the period and amplitude of trigonometric functions
message_1: A Ferris wheel has a diameter of 50 meters and it completes one rotation every 40 seconds. An observer standing at the center of the wheel records the height of a passenger as the wheel revolves. The height of the passenger can be modeled by the function h(t) = -25 cos(π/20 t) + 25, where t is time in seconds. Determine the period and amplitude of the passenger's height.
message_2:
The given function is h(t) = -25 cos(π/20 t) + 25. This is a cosine function of the form h(t) = A cos(Bt) + C, where A is the amplitude, B is the angular frequency, and C is the vertical shift.

In this case, A = -25, B = π/20, and C = 25.

The amplitude of the function is the absolute value of A, which is |-25| = 25 meters. This means that the passenger's height oscillates 25 meters above and below the center of the Ferris wheel.

To find the period of the function, we can use the formula T = 2π/B, where T is the period and B is the angular frequency.

T = 2π/(π/20) = 2π * (20/π) = 40 seconds.

So, the period of the passenger's height is 40 seconds, which matches the time it takes for the Ferris wheel to complete one rotation.

In conclusion, the amplitude of the passenger's height is 25 meters, and the period is 40 seconds.
